bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to James M. Phalen, August 9, 1927

div1.p: [Laura Carter] sends Phalen notes on Henry Carter and his work. She notes that Henry Carter excluded his living host theory from his 1900 article for fear that such speculation would make the article less acceptable.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to James M. Phalen, August 9, 1927
div1.opener:
Biographic
Phalen (Col, J. M.)
“Dunlora.” Box 453,
Charlottesville, Virginia.
August 9, 1927.
Colonel James M. Phalen,
Medical Corps, U. S. Army,
Librarian, Army Medical Library,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Colonel Phalen:
div1.p:
I wonder whether the enclosed biggraphic notes would be of any
help to you in writing your sketch on my Father? They have just been
returned to me, or I should have sent them with the data for which you
specifically asked, which went off yesterday by special delivery.

The enclosures were written last fall by Dr. Wade H. Frost, of
the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene at the request of the, then, International
Health Board of the Rockefeller Foundation. not ke they

As you will notice, in reading the original MS of “A note on the
interval between infecting and secondary cases of yellow fever” etc. (depos-
ited in your Library as a permanent loan) it contains three possible expla-
nations of the phenomenun of “extrinsic incubation,”--one that of a living host
These possible explanations, however, were omitted from the published article,
for fear that any form of speculation should detract from the definitely
data presented: by making them load accepted.

I should be very grateful for the return of the enclosed notes,
as I have no duplicates, but if, by any chance, they contain data that may
be of use to you, I trust that you will keep them as long as you wish.

With highest esteem, and looking forward with very happy anti-
cipations to reading your sketch of my Father,
